item.description: Podcast Description We speak with a governor, a former C.D.C. director, a pandemic forecaster, a hard-charging pharmacist, and a pair of economists — who say it’s all about the incentives. (Pandemillions, anyone?) Transcript

item.title: 415. How Rahm Emanuel Would Run the World | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description As a former top adviser to presidents Clinton and Obama, he believes in the power of the federal government. But as former mayor of Chicago, he says that cities are where real problems get solved — especially in the era of Covid-19. Transcript

item.title: 414. Will Covid-19 Spark a Cold War (or Worse) With China? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The U.S. spent the past few decades waiting for China to act like the global citizen it said it wanted to be. The waiting may be over. Transcript

item.title: 413. Who Gets the Ventilator? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Should a nurse or doctor who gets sick treating Covid-19 patients have priority access to a potentially life-saving healthcare device? Americans aren’t used to rationing in medicine, but it’s time to think about it. We consult a lung specialist, a bioethicist, and (of course) an economist. Transcript

item.title: 412. What Happens When Everyone Stays Home to Eat? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Covid-19 has shocked our food-supply system like nothing in modern history. We examine the winners, the losers, the unintended consequences — and just how much toilet paper one household really needs. Transcript

item.title: 411. Is $2 Trillion the Right Medicine for a Sick Economy? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Congress just passed the biggest aid package in modern history. We ask six former White House economic advisors and one U.S. Senator: Will it actually work? What are its best and worst features? Where does $2 trillion come from, and what are the long-term effects of all that government spending? Transcript

item.title: 410. What Does Covid-19 Mean for Cities (and Marriages)? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description There are a lot of upsides to urban density — but viral contagion is not one of them. Also: a nationwide lockdown will show if familiarity really breeds contempt. And: how to help your neighbor. Transcript

item.title: 409. The Side Effects of Social Distancing | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In just a few weeks, the novel coronavirus has undone a century’s worth of our economic and social habits. What consequences will this have on our future — and is there a silver lining in this very black pandemic cloud? Transcript

item.title: Why Rent Control Doesn’t Work (Ep. 373 Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description As cities become ever-more expensive, politicians and housing advocates keep calling for rent control. Economists think that’s a terrible idea. They say it helps a small (albeit noisy) group of renters, but keeps overall rents artificially high by disincentivizing new construction. So what happens next? Transcript

item.title: 408. Does Anyone Really Know What Socialism Is? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Trump says it would destroy us. Sanders says it will save us. The majority of millennials would like it to replace capitalism. But what is “it”? We bring in the economists to sort things out and tell us what the U.S. can learn from the good (and bad) experiences of other (supposedly) socialist countries. Transcript

item.title: 407. Is There Really a “Loneliness Epidemic”? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description That’s what some health officials are saying, but the data aren’t so clear. We look into what’s known (and not known) about the prevalence and effects of loneliness — including the possible upsides. Transcript

item.title: 406. Can You Hear Me Now? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description When he became chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Ajit Pai announced that he was going to take a “weed whacker” to Obama-era regulations. So far, he’s kept his promise, and earned the internet’s ire for reversing the agency’s position on net neutrality. Pai defends his actions and explains how the U.S. can “win” everything from the 5G race to the war on robocalls. Transcript

item.title: 405. Policymaking Is Not a Science (Yet) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Why do so many promising solutions — in education, medicine, criminal justice, etc. — fail to scale up into great policy? And can a new breed of “implementation scientists” crack the code? Transcript

item.title: 404. Does the President Matter as Much as You Think? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We asked this same question nearly a decade ago. The answer then: probably not. But a lot has changed since then, and we’re three years into one of the most anomalous presidencies in American history. So once again we try to sort out presidential signal from noise. What we hear from legal and policy experts may leave you surprised, befuddled — and maybe infuriated. Transcript

item.title: How the San Francisco 49ers Stopped Being Losers (Ep. 350 Update) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description One of the most storied (and valuable) sports franchises in the world had fallen far. So they decided to do a full reboot — and it worked: this week, they are headed back to the Super Bowl. Before the 2018 season, we sat down with the team’s owner, head coach, general manager, and players as they were plotting their turnaround. Here’s an update of that episode. Transcript

item.title: 403. The Opioid Tragedy, Part 2: “It’s Not a Death Sentence” | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description One prescription drug is keeping some addicts from dying. So why isn’t it more widespread? A story of regulation, stigma, and the potentially fatal faith in abstinence. Transcript

item.title: 402. The Opioid Tragedy, Part 1: “We’ve Addicted an Entire Generation” | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description How pharma greed, government subsidies, and a push to make pain the “fifth vital sign” kicked off a crisis that costs $80 billion a year and has killed hundreds of thousands of Americans. Transcript

item.title: 5 Psychology Terms You’re Probably Misusing (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We all like to throw around terms that describe human behavior — “bystander apathy” and “steep learning curve” and “hard-wired.” Most of the time, they don’t actually mean what we think they mean. But don’t worry — the experts are getting it wrong, too. Transcript

item.title: The Zero-Minute Workout (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description There is strong evidence that exercise is wildly beneficial. There is even stronger evidence that most people hate to exercise. So if a pill could mimic the effects of working out, why wouldn’t we want to take it? Transcript

item.title: 401. How Many Prince Charleses Can There Be in One Room? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In a special holiday episode, Stephen Dubner and Angela Duckworth take turns asking each other questions about charisma, wealth vs. intellect, and (of course) grit. Transcript

item.title: Why Is This Man Running for President? (Update) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A year ago, nobody was taking Andrew Yang very seriously. Now he is America’s favorite entrepre-nerd, with a candidacy that keeps gaining momentum. This episode includes our Jan. 2019 conversation with the leader of the Yang Gang and a fresh interview recorded from the campaign trail in Iowa. Transcript

item.title: 400. How to Hate Taxes a Little Bit Less | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Every year, Americans short the I.R.S. nearly half a trillion dollars. Most ideas to increase compliance are more stick than carrot — scary letters, audits, and penalties. But what if we gave taxpayers a chance to allocate how their money is spent, or even bribed them with a thank-you gift? Transcript

item.title: 399. Honey, I Grew the Economy | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Innovation experts have long overlooked where a lot of innovation actually happens. The personal computer, the mountain bike, the artificial pancreas — none of these came from some big R&D lab, but from users tinkering in their homes. Acknowledging this reality — and encouraging it — would be good for the economy (and the soul too). Transcript

item.title: How to Change Your Mind (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description There are a lot of barriers to changing your mind: ego, overconfidence, inertia — and cost. Politicians who flip-flop get mocked; family and friends who cross tribal borders are shunned. But shouldn’t we be encouraging people to change their minds? And how can we get better at it ourselves? Transcript

item.title: 398. The Truth About the Vaping Crisis | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A recent outbreak of illness and death has gotten everyone’s attention — including late-to-the-game regulators. But would a ban on e-cigarettes do more harm than good? We smoke out the facts. Transcript

item.title: 397. How to Save $32 Million in One Hour | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description For nearly a decade, governments have been using behavioral nudges to solve problems — and the strategy is catching on in healthcare, firefighting, and policing. But is that thinking too small? Could nudging be used to fight income inequality and achieve world peace? Recorded live in London, with commentary from Andy Zaltzman (The Bugle). Transcript

item.title: 396. Why Does Tipping Still Exist? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It’s an acutely haphazard way of paying workers, and yet it keeps expanding. We dig into the data to find out why. Transcript

item.title: 395. Speak Softly and Carry Big Data | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Do economic sanctions work? Are big democracies any good at spreading democracy? What is the root cause of terrorism? It turns out that data analysis can help answer all these questions — and make better foreign-policy decisions. Guests include former Department of Defense officials Chuck Hagel and Michèle Flournoy and Chicago Project on Security and Threats researchers Robert Pape and Paul Poast. Recorded live in Chicago; Steve Levitt is co-host.

item.title: 394. Does Hollywood Still Have a Princess Problem? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description For decades, there’s been a huge gender disparity both on-screen and behind the scenes. But it seems like cold, hard data — with an assist from the actor Geena Davis — may finally be moving the needle. Transcript

item.title: 393. Can Britain Get Its “Great” Back? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It used to be a global capital of innovation, invention, and exploration. Now it’s best known for its messy European divorce. We visit London to see if the British spirit of discovery is still alive. Guests include the mayor of London, undersea explorers, a time-use researcher, and a theoretical physicist who helped Liverpool win the Champions League. Dan Schreiber from No Such Thing as a Fish rides shotgun.

item.title: 392. The Prime Minister Who Cried Brexit | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In 2016, David Cameron held a referendum on whether the U.K. should stay in the European Union. A longtime Euroskeptic, he nevertheless led the Remain campaign. So what did Cameron really want? We ask him that and much more — including why he left office as soon as his side lost and what he’d do differently if given another chance. (Hint: not much.) Transcript

item.title: 391. America’s Math Curriculum Doesn’t Add Up | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Most high-school math classes are still preparing students for the Sputnik era. Steve Levitt wants to get rid of the “geometry sandwich” and instead have kids learn what they really need in the modern era: data fluency. Transcript

item.title: 390. Fed Up | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Mary Daly rose from high-school dropout to president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. She thinks the central bank needs an upgrade too. It starts with recognizing that the economy is made up of actual humans. Transcript

item.title: 389. How to Make Meetings Less Terrible | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In the U.S. alone, we hold 55 million meetings a day. Most of them are woefully unproductive, and tyrannize our offices. The revolution begins now — with better agendas, smaller invite lists, and an embrace of healthy conflict. Transcript

item.title: Yes, the Open Office Is Terrible — But It Doesn’t Have to Be (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It began as a post-war dream for a more collaborative and egalitarian workplace. It has evolved into a nightmare of noise and discomfort. Can the open office be saved, or should we all just be working from home? Transcript

item.title: 388. The Economics of Sports Gambling | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What happens when tens of millions of fantasy-sports players are suddenly able to bet real money on real games? We’re about to find out. A recent Supreme Court decision has cleared the way to bring an estimated $300 billion in black-market sports betting into the light. We sort out the winners and losers. Transcript

item.title: The Future of Meat (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Global demand for beef, chicken, and pork continues to rise. So do concerns about environmental and other costs. Will reconciling these two forces be possible — or, even better, Impossible™? Transcript

item.title: Should America Be Run by … Trader Joe’s? (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The quirky little grocery chain with California roots and German ownership has a lot to teach all of us about choice architecture, efficiency, frugality, collaboration, and team spirit. Transcript

item.title: 387. Hello, My Name Is Marijuana Pepsi! | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Research shows that having a distinctively black name doesn’t affect your economic future. But what is the day-to-day reality of living with such a name? Marijuana Pepsi Vandyck, a newly-minted Ph.D., is well-qualified to answer this question. Her verdict: the data don’t tell the whole story. Transcript

item.title: How Much Does Your Name Matter? (Rebroadcast ) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A kid’s name can tell us something about his parents — their race, social standing, even their politics. But is your name really your destiny? Transcript

item.title: 386. How the Supermarket Helped America Win the Cold War | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Aisle upon aisle of fresh produce, cheap meat, and sugary cereal — a delicious embodiment of free-market capitalism, right? Not quite. The supermarket was in fact the endpoint of the U.S. government’s battle for agricultural abundance against the U.S.S.R. Our farm policies were built to dominate, not necessarily to nourish — and we are still living with the consequences. Transcript

item.title: America’s Hidden Duopoly (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We all know our political system is “broken” — but what if that’s not true? Some say the Republicans and Democrats constitute a wildly successful industry that has colluded to kill off competition, stifle reform, and drive the country apart. So what are you going to do about it? Transcript

item.title: 385. What Do Nancy Pelosi, Taylor Swift, and Serena Williams Have in Common? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description They — along with a great many other high-achieving women — were all once Girl Scouts. So was Sylvia Acevedo. Raised in a poor, immigrant family, she was told that “girls like her” didn’t go to college. But she did, and then became a rocket scientist and tech executive. Now she’s C.E.O. of the very organization she credits with shaping her life. Acevedo tells us how the Girl Scouts are trying to stay relevant, why they’re suing the Boy Scouts, and how they sell so many cookies.

item.title: 384. Abortion and Crime, Revisited | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The controversial theory linking Roe v. Wade to a massive crime drop is back in the spotlight as several states introduce abortion restrictions. Steve Levitt and John Donohue discuss their original research, the challenges to its legitimacy, and their updated analysis. Also: what this means for abortion policy, crime policy, and having intelligent conversations about contentious topics. Transcript

item.title: A Better Way to Eat (Rebroadcast ) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Takeru Kobayashi revolutionized the sport of competitive eating. What can the rest of us learn from his breakthrough? Transcript

item.title: 383. The Zero-Minute Workout | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description There is strong evidence that exercise is wildly beneficial. There is even stronger evidence that most people hate to exercise. So if a pill could mimic the effects of working out, why wouldn’t we want to take it? Transcript

item.title: 382. How Goes the Behavior-Change Revolution? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description An all-star team of behavioral scientists discovers that humans are stubborn (and lazy, and sometimes dumber than dogs). We also hear about binge drinking, humblebragging, and regrets. Recorded live in Philadelphia with guests including Richard Thaler, Angela Duckworth, Katy Milkman, and Tom Gilovich. Transcript

item.title: 381. Long-Term Thinking in a Start-Up Town | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Recorded live in San Francisco. Guests include the keeper of a 10,000-year clock, the co-founder of Lyft, a pioneer in male birth control, a specialist in water security, and a psychology professor who is also a puppy. With co-host Angela Duckworth, fact-checker Mike Maughan, and the Freakonomics Radio Orchestra. Transcript

item.title: 380. Notes From an Imperfect Paradise | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Recorded live in Los Angeles. Guests include Mayor Eric Garcetti, the “Earthquake Lady,” the head of the Port of L.A., and a scientist with NASA’s Planetary Protection team. With co-host Angela Duckworth, fact-checker Mike Maughan, and the worldwide debut of Luis Guerra and the Freakonomics Radio Orchestra. Transcript

item.title: 379. How to Change Your Mind | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description There are a lot of barriers to changing your mind: ego, overconfidence, inertia — and cost. Politicians who flip-flop get mocked; family and friends who cross tribal borders are shunned. But shouldn’t we be encouraging people to change their minds? And how can we get better at it ourselves? Transcript

item.title: Here’s Why All Your Projects Are Always Late — and What to Do About It (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Whether it’s a giant infrastructure plan or a humble kitchen renovation, it’ll inevitably take way too long and cost way too much. That’s because you suffer from “the planning fallacy.” (You also have an “optimism bias” and a bad case of overconfidence.) But don’t worry: we’ve got the solution. Transcript

item.title: 378. 23andMe (and You, and Everyone Else) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The revolution in home DNA testing is giving consumers important, possibly life-changing information. It’s also building a gigantic database that could lead to medical breakthroughs. But how will you deal with upsetting news? What if your privacy is compromised? And are you prepared to have your DNA monetized? We speak with Anne Wojcicki, founder and C.E.O. of 23andMe. Transcript

item.title: 377. The $1.5 Trillion Question-How to fix student loan debt? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description As the cost of college skyrocketed, it created a debt burden that’s putting a drag on the economy. One possible solution: shifting the risk of debt away from students and onto investors looking for a cut of the graduates’ earning power. Transcript

item.title: 376. The Data-Driven Guide to Sane Parenting | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Humans have been having kids forever, so why are modern parents so bewildered? The economist Emily Oster marshals the evidence on the most contentious topics — breastfeeding and sleep training, vaccines and screen time — and tells her fellow parents to calm the heck down. Transcript

item.title: The Invisible Paw (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Humans, it has long been thought, are the only animal to engage in economic activity. But what if we’ve had it exactly backward? Transcript

item.title: 375. The Most Interesting Fruit in the World | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The banana used to be a luxury good. Now it’s the most popular fruit in the U.S. and elsewhere. But the production efficiencies that made it so cheap have also made it vulnerable to a deadly fungus that may wipe out the one variety most of us eat. Scientists do have a way to save it — but will Big Banana let them? Transcript

item.title: 374. How Spotify Saved the Music Industry (But Not Necessarily Musicians) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Daniel Ek, a 23-year-old Swede who grew up on pirated music, made the record labels an offer they couldn’t refuse: a legal platform to stream all the world’s music. Spotify reversed the labels’ fortunes, made Ek rich, and thrilled millions of music fans. But what has it done for all those musicians stuck in the long tail? Transcript

item.title: 373. Why Rent Control Doesn’t Work | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description As cities become ever-more expensive, politicians and housing advocates keep calling for rent control. Economists think that’s a terrible idea. They say it helps a small (albeit noisy) group of renters, but keeps overall rents artificially high by disincentivizing new construction. So what happens next? Transcript

item.title: 372. Freakonomics Radio Live: “Would You Eat a Piece of Chocolate Shaped Like Dog Poop?” | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What your disgust level says about your politics, how Napoleon influenced opera, why New York City’s subways may finally run on time, and more. Five compelling guests tell Stephen Dubner, co-host Angela Duckworth, and fact-checker Jody Avirgan lots of things they didn’t know. Transcript

item.title: Why You Shouldn’t Open a Restaurant (Update) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Kenji Lopez-Alt became a rock star of the food world by bringing science into the kitchen in a way that everyday cooks can appreciate. Then he dared to start his own restaurant — and discovered problems that even science can’t solve. Transcript

item.title: 371. A Free-Trade Democrat in the Trump White House | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description For years, Gary Cohn thought he’d be the next C.E.O. of Goldman Sachs. Instead, he became the “adult in the room” in a chaotic administration. Cohn talks about the fights he won, the fights he lost, and the fights he was no longer willing to have. Also: why he and Trump are still on speaking terms even after he reportedly called the president “a professional liar.” Transcript

item.title: 370. How to Fail Like a Pro | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The road to success is paved with failure, so you might as well learn to do it right. (Ep. 5 of the “How to Be Creative” series.) Transcript

item.title: 369. A Good Idea Is Not Good Enough | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Whether you’re building a business or a cathedral, execution is everything. We ask artists, scientists, and inventors how they turned ideas into reality. And we find out why it’s so hard for a group to get things done — and what you can do about it. (Ep. 4 of the “How to Be Creative” series.) Transcript

item.title: 368. Where Do Good Ideas Come From? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Whether you’re mapping the universe, hosting a late-night talk show, or running a meeting, there are a lot of ways to up your idea game. Plus: the truth about brainstorming. (Ep. 3 of the “How to Be Creative” series.) Transcript

item.title: 367. The Future of Meat | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Global demand for beef, chicken, and pork continues to rise. So do concerns about environmental and other costs. Will reconciling these two forces be possible — or, even better, Impossible™? Transcript

item.title: 366. This Economist Predicted the Last Crisis. What’s the Next One? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In 2005, Raghuram Rajan said the financial system was at risk “of a catastrophic meltdown.” After stints at the I.M.F. and India’s central bank, he sees another potential crisis — and he offers a solution. Is it stronger governments? Freer markets? Rajan’s answer: neither. Transcript

item.title: Extra: Domonique Foxworth Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversation with the former N.F.L. player, union official, and all-around sports thinker, recorded for our “Hidden Side of Sports” series. Transcript

item.title: 365. Not Just Another Labor Force | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description If you think talent and hard work give top athletes all the leverage to succeed, think again. As employees in the Sports-Industrial Complex, they’ve got a tight earnings window, a high injury rate, little choice in where they work — and a very early forced retirement. (Ep. 6 of “The Hidden Side of Sports” series.) Transcript

item.title: Extra: Mark Cuban Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A conversation with the Shark Tank star, entrepreneur, and Dallas Mavericks owner recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Hidden Side of Sports.” Transcript

item.title: 364. Inside the Sports-Industrial Complex | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description For most of us, the athletes are what make sports interesting. But if you own the team or run the league, your players are essentially very expensive migrant workers who eat into your profits. We talk to N.F.L., N.B.A., and U.F.C. executives about labor costs, viewership numbers, legalized gambling, and the rise of e-sports. (Ep. 5 of “The Hidden Side of Sports” series.) Transcript

item.title: Extra: Mark Teixeira Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A conversation with former Major League Baseball player and current ESPN analyst Mark Teixeira, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Hidden Side of Sports.” Transcript

item.title: 363. Think Like a Winner | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Great athletes aren’t just great at the physical stuff. They’ve also learned how to handle pressure, overcome fear, and stay focused. Here’s the good news: you don’t have to be an athlete to use what they know. (Ep. 4 of “The Hidden Side of Sports” series.) Transcript

item.title: Hacking the World Bank (Update) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Jim Yong Kim has an unorthodox background for a World Bank president — and his reign has been just as unorthodox. He has just announced he’s stepping down, well before his term is over; we recorded this interview with him in 2015. Transcript

item.title: 362. Why Is This Man Running for President? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In the American Dream sweepstakes, Andrew Yang was a pretty big winner. But for every winner, he came to realize, there are thousands upon thousands of losers — a “war on normal people,” he calls it. Here’s what he plans to do about it. Transcript

item.title: How to Be Happy (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The U.N.’s World Happiness Report — created to curtail our unhealthy obsession with G.D.P. — is dominated every year by the Nordic countries. We head to Denmark to learn the secrets of this happiness epidemic (and to see if we should steal them). Transcript

item.title: How to Win Games and Beat People (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Games are as old as civilization itself, and some people think they have huge social value regardless of whether you win or lose. Tom Whipple is not one of those people. That’s why he consulted an army of preposterously overqualified experts to find the secret to winning any game. Transcript

item.title: People Aren’t Dumb. The World Is Hard. (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description You wouldn’t think you could win a Nobel Prize for showing that humans tend to make irrational decisions. But that’s what Richard Thaler has done. The founder of behavioral economics describes his unlikely route to success; his reputation for being lazy; and his efforts to fix the world — one nudge at a time. Transcript

item.title: Freakonomics Radio Live: “The World’s a Mess. But Oysters, They Hold it Down.” | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Celebrity chef Alex Guarnaschelli joins us to co-host an evening of delicious fact-finding: where a trillion oysters went, whether a soda tax can work, and how beer helped build an empire. Washington Post columnist Alexandra Petri is our real-time fact-checker. Transcript

item.title: Freakonomics Radio Live: “We Thought of a Way to Manipulate Your Perception of Time.” | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We learn how to be less impatient, how to tell fake news from real, and the simple trick that nurses used to make better predictions than doctors. Journalist Manoush Zomorodi co-hosts; our real-time fact-checker is the author and humorist A.J. Jacobs. Transcript

item.title: Freakonomics Radio Live: “Where Does Fear Live in the Brain?” | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Our co-host is comedian Christian Finnegan, and we learn: the difference between danger and fear; the role of clouds in climate change; and why (and when) politicians are bad at math. Washington Post columnist Alexandra Petri is our real-time fact-checker. Transcript

item.title: 361. Freakonomics Radio Live: “Jesus Could Have Been a Pigeon.” | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Our co-host is Grit author Angela Duckworth, and we learn fascinating, Freakonomical facts from a parade of guests. For instance: what we all get wrong about Darwin; what an iPod has in common with the “hell ant”; and how a “memory athlete” memorizes a deck of cards. Mike Maughan is our real-time fact-checker. Transcript

item.title: 360. Is the Protestant Work Ethic Real? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In the early 20th century, Max Weber argued that Protestantism created wealth. Finally, there are data to prove if he was right. All it took were some missionary experiments in the Philippines and a clever map-matching trick that goes back to 16th-century Germany. Transcript

item.title: 359. Should America Be Run by … Trader Joe’s? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The quirky little grocery chain with California roots and German ownership has a lot to teach all of us about choice architecture, efficiency, frugality, collaboration, and team spirit. Transcript

item.title: There’s a War on Sugar. Is It Justified? (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Some people argue that sugar should be regulated, like alcohol and tobacco, on the grounds that it’s addictive and toxic. How much sense does that make? We hear from a regulatory advocate, an evidence-based skeptic, a former F.D.A. commissioner — and the organizers of Milktoberfest. Transcript

item.title: 358. Yes, the Open Office Is Terrible — But It Doesn’t Have to Be | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It began as a post-war dream for a more collaborative and egalitarian workplace. It has evolved into a nightmare of noise and discomfort. Can the open office be saved, or should we all just be working from home? Transcript

item.title: 357. Can an Industrial Giant Become a Tech Darling? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The Ford Motor Company is ditching its legacy sedans, doubling down on trucks, and trying to steer its stock price out of a long skid. But C.E.O. Jim Hackett has even bigger plans: to turn a century-old automaker into the nucleus of a “transportation operating system.” Is Hackett just whistling past the graveyard, or does he see what others can’t? Transcript

item.title: 356. America’s Hidden Duopoly | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We all know our political system is “broken” — but what if that’s not true? Some say the Republicans and Democrats constitute a wildly successful industry that has colluded to kill off competition, stifle reform, and drive the country apart. So what are you going to do about it? Transcript

item.title: Extra: Elvis Costello Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A conversation with the iconic singer-songwriter, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “How to Be Creative.” Transcript

item.title: 355. Where Does Creativity Come From (and Why Do Schools Kill It Off)? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Family environments and “diversifying experiences” (including the early death of a parent); intrinsic versus extrinsic motivations; schools that value assessments, but don’t assess the things we value. All these elements factor into the long, mysterious march towards a creative life. To learn more, we examine the early years of Ai Weiwei, Rosanne Cash, Elvis Costello, Maira Kalman, Wynton Marsalis, Jennifer Egan, and others. (Ep. 2 of the “How to Be Creative” series.

item.title: Extra: Jeremy Lin Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A conversation with veteran NBA point guard Jeremy Lin, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Hidden Side of Sports.” Transcript

item.title: 354. How to Be Creative | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description There are thousands of books on the subject, but what do we actually know about creativity? In this new series, we talk to the researchers who study it as well as artists, inventors, and pathbreakers who live it every day: Ai Weiwei, James Dyson, Elvis Costello, Jennifer Egan, Rosanne Cash, Wynton Marsalis, Maira Kalman, and more. (Ep. 1 of the “How to Be Creative” series.) Transcript

item.title: 353. How to Optimize Your Apology | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description You said, “I’m sorry,” but somehow you haven’t been forgiven. Why? Because you’re doing it wrong! A report from the front lines of apology science. Transcript

item.title: 352. Can This Man Stop a Trade War? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The World Trade Organization is the referee for 164 trading partners, each with their own political and economic agendas. Lately, those agendas have gotten more complicated — especially with President Trump’s tariff blitz. Roberto Azevêdo, head of the W.T.O., tells us why it’s so hard to balance protectionism and globalism; what’s really behind the loss of jobs; and what he’d say to Trump (if he ever gets the chance).

item.title: Extra: Shawn Johnson Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A conversation with 2008 Olympic gold medalist Shawn Johnson, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Hidden Side of Sports.” Transcript

item.title: 351. Here’s Why You’re Not an Elite Athlete | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description There are a lot of factors that go into greatness, many of which are not obvious. A variety of Olympic and professional athletes tell us how they made it and what they sacrificed to get there. And if you can identify the sport most likely to get a kid into a top college — well then, touché! (Ep. 3 of “The Hidden Side of Sports” series.) Transcript

item.title: Extra: Full Interviews With Jimmy Garoppolo, Joe Staley, Mike McGlinchey, and Kyle Juszczyk | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversations with members of the San Francisco 49ers offense, recorded for Freakonomics Radio episode No. 350, part of the “Hidden Side of Sports” series. Transcript

item.title: 350. How to Stop Being a Loser | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The San Francisco 49ers, one of the most valuable sports franchises in the world, also used to be one of the best. But they’ve been losing lately — a lot — and one of their players launched a controversy by taking a knee during the national anthem. So why is everyone there so optimistic? To find out, we speak with the team’s owner, head coach, general manager, and star players, including their new $137.

item.title: 349. How Sports Became Us | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Dollar-wise, the sports industry is surprisingly small, about the same size as the cardboard-box industry. So why does it make so much noise? Because it reflects — and often amplifies — just about every political, economic, and social issue of the day. Introducing a new series, “The Hidden Side of Sports.” Transcript

item.title: 348. Is the Government More Entrepreneurial Than You Think? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We all know the standard story: our economy would be more dynamic if only the government would get out of the way. The economist Mariana Mazzucato says we’ve got that story backward. She argues that the government, by funding so much early-stage research, is hugely responsible for big successes in tech, pharma, energy, and more. But the government also does a terrible job in claiming credit — and, more important, getting a return on its investment.

item.title: 347. Why You Shouldn’t Open a Restaurant | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Kenji Lopez-Alt became a rock star of the food world by bringing science into the kitchen in a way that everyday cooks can appreciate. Then he dared to start his own restaurant — and discovered problems that even science can’t solve. Transcript

item.title: 346. Two (Totally Opposite) Ways to Save the Planet | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The environmentalists say we’re doomed if we don’t drastically reduce consumption. The technologists say that human ingenuity can solve just about any problem. A debate that’s been around for decades has become a shouting match. Is anyone right? Transcript

item.title: 345. How to Be Happy | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The U.N.’s World Happiness Report — created to curtail our unhealthy obsession with G.D.P. — is dominated every year by the Nordic countries. We head to Denmark to learn the secrets of this happiness epidemic (and to see if we should steal them). Transcript

item.title: 344. Who Decides How Much a Life Is Worth? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description After every mass shooting or terrorist attack, victims and survivors receive a huge outpouring of support — including a massive pool of compensation money. How should that money be allocated? We speak with the man who’s done that job after many tragedies, including 9/11. The hard part, it turns out, isn’t attaching a dollar figure to each victim; the hard part is acknowledging that dollars can’t heal the pain.

item.title: A Conversation With PepsiCo C.E.O. Indra Nooyi (Ep. 316 Update) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description One of the world’s biggest and best-known companies just announced that its C.E.O. would be stepping down in the fall. We interviewed her as part of our series “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.," and we thought you might like to hear that episode again, or for the first time if you missed it back then. Transcript

item.title: 343. An Astronaut, a Catalan, and Two Linguists Walk Into a Bar… | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In this live episode of “Tell Me Something I Don’t Know,” we learn why New York has skinny skyscrapers, how to weaponize water, and what astronauts talk about in space. Joining Stephen J. Dubner as co-host is the linguist John McWhorter; Bari Weiss (The New York Times) is the real-time fact-checker. Transcript

item.title: 342. Has Lance Armstrong Finally Come Clean? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description He was once the most lionized athlete on the planet, with seven straight Tour de France wins and a victory over cancer too. Then the doping charges caught up with him. When he finally confessed to Oprah, he admits, “it didn’t go well at all.” That’s because he wasn’t actually contrite yet. Now, five years later, he says he is. Do you believe him? Transcript

item.title: 341. Why We Choke Under Pressure (and How Not To) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It happens to just about everyone, whether you’re going for Olympic gold or giving a wedding toast. We hear from psychologists, economists, and the golfer who some say committed the greatest choke of all time. Transcript

item.title: 340. People Aren’t Dumb. The World Is Hard. | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description You wouldn’t think you could win a Nobel Prize for showing that humans tend to make irrational decisions. But that’s what Richard Thaler has done. The founder of behavioral economics describes his unlikely route to success; his reputation for being lazy; and his efforts to fix the world — one nudge at a time. Transcript

item.title: 339. The Future of Freakonomics Radio | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description After 8 years and more than 300 episodes, it was time to either 1) quit, or 2) make the show bigger and better. We voted for number 2. Here’s a peek behind the curtain and a preview of what you’ll be hearing next. Transcript

item.title: In Praise of Incrementalism (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What do Renaissance painting, civil-rights movements, and Olympic cycling have in common? In each case, huge breakthroughs came from taking tiny steps. In a world where everyone is looking for the next moonshot, we shouldn’t ignore the power of incrementalism. Transcript

item.title: In Praise of Maintenance (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Has our culture’s obsession with innovation led us to neglect the fact that things also need to be taken care of? Transcript

item.title: 338. How to Catch World Cup Fever | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description For soccer fans, it’s easy. For the rest of us? Not so much, especially since the U.S. team didn’t qualify. So here’s what to watch for even if you have no team to root for. Because the World Cup isn’t just a gargantuan sporting evént; it’s a microcosm of human foibles and (yep) economic theory brought to life. Transcript

item.title: 337. How to Build a Smart City | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We are in the midst of a historic (and wholly unpredicted) rise in urbanization. But it’s hard to retrofit old cities for the 21st century. Enter Dan Doctoroff. The man who helped modernize New York City — and tried to bring the Olympics there — is now C.E.O. of a Google-funded startup that is building, from scratch, the city of the future. Transcript

item.title: How Stupid Is Our Obsession With Lawns? (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Nearly two percent of America is grassy green. Sure, lawns are beautiful and useful and they smell great. But are the costs — financial, environmental and otherwise — worth the benefits? Transcript

item.title: 336. The Most Vilified Industry in America Is Also the Most Charitable | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Pharmaceutical firms donate an enormous amount of their products (and some cash too). But it doesn’t seem to be helping their reputation. We ask Pfizer’s generosity chief why the company gives so much, who it really helps, and whether all this philanthropy is just corporate whitewashing. Transcript

item.title: 335. Does Doing Good Give You License to Be Bad? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Corporate Social Responsibility programs can attract better job applicants who’ll work for less money. But they also encourage employees to misbehave. Don’t laugh — you too probably engage in “moral licensing,” even if you don’t know it. Transcript

item.title: 334. 5 Psychology Terms You’re Probably Misusing | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We all like to throw around terms that describe human behavior — “bystander apathy” and “steep learning curve” and “hard-wired.” Most of the time, they don’t actually mean what we think they mean. But don’t worry — the experts are getting it wrong, too. Transcript

item.title: Evolution, Accelerated (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A breakthrough in genetic technology has given humans more power than ever to change nature. It could help eliminate hunger and disease; it could also lead to the sort of dystopia we used to only read about in sci-fi novels. So what happens next? Transcript

item.title: 333. The Most Ambitious Thing Humans Have Ever Attempted | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Sure, medical progress has been astounding. But today the U.S. spends more on healthcare than any other country, with so-so outcomes. Atul Gawande — cancer surgeon, public-health researcher, and best-selling author — has some simple ideas for treating a painfully complex system. Transcript

item.title: 332. Why the Trump Tax Cuts Are Terrible/Awesome (Part 2) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Three former White House economists weigh in on the new tax bill. A sample: “The overwhelming evidence is that the trickle-down, magic-beanstalk beans argument — that’s just nonsense.” Transcript

item.title: 331. Why the Trump Tax Cuts are Awesome/Terrible (Part 1) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Kevin Hassett, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, explains the thinking behind the controversial new Republican tax package — and why its critics are wrong. (Next week, we’ll hear from the critics.) Transcript

item.title: 330. Extra: Ray Dalio Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversation with the founder and longtime C.E.O. of Bridgewater Associates, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” Transcript

item.title: 329. The Invisible Paw | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Humans, it has long been thought, are the only animal to engage in economic activity. But what if we’ve had it exactly backward? Transcript

item.title: 328. Extra: Mark Zuckerberg Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversation with the Facebook founder and C.E.O., recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” Transcript

item.title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Money (But Were Afraid to Ask) (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The bad news: roughly 70 percent of Americans are financially illiterate. The good news: all the important stuff can fit on one index card. Here’s how to become your own financial superhero. Transcript

item.title: 327. Extra: Carol Bartz Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversation with the former C.E.O. of Yahoo, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” Transcript

item.title: The Stupidest Thing You Can Do With Your Money (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It’s hard enough to save for a house, tuition, or retirement. So why are we willing to pay big fees for subpar investment returns? Enter the low-cost index fund. The revolution will not be monetized. Transcript

item.title: 326. Extra: Jack Welch Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversation with the former longtime C.E.O. of General Electric, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” Transcript

item.title: 325. How to Train Your Dragon Child | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Every 12 years, there’s a spike in births among certain communities across the globe, including the U.S. Why? Because the Year of the Dragon, according to Chinese folk belief, confers power, fortune, and more. We look at what happens to Dragon babies when they grow up, and why timing your kid’s birth based on the zodiac isn’t as ridiculous it sounds. Transcript

item.title: 324. Extra: Satya Nadella Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversation with the C.E.O. of Microsoft, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” Transcript

item.title: 323. Here’s Why All Your Projects Are Always Late — and What to Do About It | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Whether it’s a giant infrastructure plan or a humble kitchen renovation, it’ll inevitably take way too long and cost way too much. That’s because you suffer from “the planning fallacy.” (You also have an “optimism bias” and a bad case of overconfidence.) But don’t worry: we’ve got the solution. Transcript

item.title: 322. Extra: David Rubenstein Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversation with the co-founder and longtime co-C.E.O. of the Carlyle Group, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” Transcript

item.title: Does “Early Education” Come Way Too Late? (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In our collective zeal to reform schools and close the achievement gap, we may have lost sight of where most learning really happens — at home. Transcript

item.title: 321. Extra: Richard Branson Full Interview | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen Dubner’s conversation with the Virgin Group founder, recorded for the Freakonomics Radio series “The Secret Life of a C.E.O.” Transcript

item.title: 320. Letting Go | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description If you’re a C.E.O., there are a lot of ways to leave your job, from abrupt firing to carefully planned succession (which may still go spectacularly wrong). In this final episode of our “Secret Life of a C.E.O.” series, we hear those stories and many more. Also: what happens when you no longer have a corner office to go to — and how will you spend all that money?

item.title: 319. After the Glass Ceiling, a Glass Cliff | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Only 5 percent of Fortune 500 companies are run by women. Why? Research shows that female executives are more likely to be put in charge of firms that are already in crisis. Are they being set up to fail? (Part 5 of a special series, “The Secret Life of C.E.O.’s.”) Transcript

item.title: 318. It’s Your Problem Now | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description No, it’s not your fault the economy crashed. Or that consumer preferences changed. Or that new technologies have blown apart your business model. But if you’re the C.E.O., it is your problem. So what are you going to do about it? First-hand stories of disaster (and triumph) from Mark Zuckerberg, Steve Ballmer, Satya Nadella, Jack Welch, Ellen Pao, Richard Branson, and more. (Part 4 of a special series, “The Secret Life of C.

item.title: 317. What Can Uber Teach Us About the Gender Pay Gap? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The gig economy offers the ultimate flexibility to set your own hours. That’s why economists thought it would help eliminate the gender pay gap. A new study, using data from over a million Uber drivers, finds the story isn’t so simple. Transcript

item.title: An Egghead’s Guide to the Super Bowl (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We assembled a panel of smart dudes – a two-time Super Bowl champ; a couple of N.F.L. linemen, including one who’s getting a math Ph.D. at MIT; and our resident economist – to tell you what to watch for, whether you’re a football fanatic or a total newbie. Transcript

item.title: 316. “I Wasn’t Stupid Enough to Say This Could Be Done Overnight” | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Indra Nooyi became C.E.O. of PepsiCo just in time for a global financial meltdown. She also had a portfolio full of junk food just as the world decided that junk food is borderline toxic. Here’s the story of how she overhauled that portfolio, stared down activist investors, and learned to “leave the crown in the garage.” (Part 3 of a special series, “The Secret Life of C.E.O.’s”) Transcript

item.title: 315. How to Become a C.E.O. | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Mark Zuckerberg’s dentist dad was an early adopter of digital x-rays. Jack Welch blew the roof off a factory. Carol Bartz was a Wisconsin farm girl who got into computers. No two C.E.O.’s have the same origin story — so we tell them all! How the leaders of Facebook, G.E., Yahoo!, PepsiCo, Microsoft, Virgin, the Carlyle Group, Reddit, and Bridgewater Associates made it to the top. (Part 2 of a special series, “The Secret Life of C.

item.title: 314. What Does a C.E.O. Actually Do? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description They’re paid a fortune — but for what, exactly? What makes a good C.E.O. — and how can you even tell? Is “leadership science” a real thing — or just airport-bookstore mumbo jumbo? We put these questions to Mark Zuckerberg, Richard Branson, Indra Nooyi, Satya Nadella, Jack Welch, Ray Dalio, Carol Bartz, David Rubenstein, and Ellen Pao. (Part 1 of a special series, “The Secret Life of C.E.O.’s.”)

item.title: 313. How to Be a Modern Democrat — and Win | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Gina Raimondo, the governor of tiny Rhode Island, has taken on unions, boosted big business, and made friends with Republicans. She is also one of just 15 Democratic governors in the country. Would there be more of them if there were more like her? Transcript

item.title: Why Is My Life So Hard? (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Most of us feel we face more headwinds and obstacles than everyone else — which breeds resentment. We also undervalue the tailwinds that help us — which leaves us ungrateful and unhappy. How can we avoid this trap? Transcript

item.title: Trust Me (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Societies where people trust one another are healthier and wealthier. In the U.S. (and the U.K. and elsewhere), social trust has been falling for decades — in part because our populations are more diverse. What can we do to fix it? Transcript

item.title: Make Me a Match (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Sure, markets generally work well. But for some transactions — like school admissions and organ transplants — money alone can’t solve the problem. That’s when you need a market-design wizard like Al Roth. Transcript

item.title: 312. Not Your Grandmother’s I.M.F. | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The International Monetary Fund has long been the “lender of last resort” for economies in crisis. Christine Lagarde, who runs the institution, would like to prevent those crises from ever happening. She tells us her plans. Transcript

item.title: 311. Why Is the Live-Event Ticket Market So Screwed Up? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The public has almost no chance to buy good tickets to the best events. Ticket brokers, meanwhile, make huge profits on the secondary markets. Here’s the story of how this market got so dysfunctional, how it can be fixed – and why it probably won’t be. Transcript

item.title: 310. Are We Running Out of Ideas? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Economists have a hard time explaining why productivity growth has been shrinking. One theory: true innovation has gotten much harder – and much more expensive. So what should we do next? Transcript

item.title: Is America Ready for a “No-Lose Lottery”? (Update) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Most people don’t enjoy the simple, boring act of putting money in a savings account. But we do love to play the lottery. So what if you combine the two, creating a new kind of savings account with a lottery payout? Transcript

item.title: 309. Nurses to the Rescue! | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description They are the most-trusted profession in America (and with good reason). They are critical to patient outcomes (especially in primary care). Could the growing army of nurse practitioners be an answer to the doctor shortage? The data say yes but — big surprise — doctors’ associations say no. Transcript

item.title: 308. How Can I Do the Most Social Good With $100? And Other FREAK-quently Asked Questions | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Dubner and his Freakonomics co-author Steve Levitt answer your questions about crime, traffic, real-estate agents, the Ph.D. glut, and how to not get eaten by a bear. Transcript

item.title: Why Is There So Much Ground Beef in the World? (Special Feature) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In this live episode of “Tell Me Something I Don’t Know,” you’ll learn about carcass balancing, teen sleeping, and brand naming. Joining Stephen J. Dubner as co-host is Alex Wagner (CBS This Morning Saturday); author A.J. Jacobs (It’s All Relative) is the live fact-checker. Transcript

item.title: 307. Thinking Is Expensive. Who’s Supposed to Pay for It? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Corporations and rich people donate billions to their favorite think tanks and foundations. Should we be grateful for their generosity — or suspicious of their motives? Transcript

item.title: 306. How to Launch a Behavior-Change Revolution | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Academic studies are nice, and so are Nobel Prizes. But to truly prove the value of a new idea, you have to unleash it to the masses. That’s what a dream team of social scientists is doing — and we sat in as they drew up their game plan. Transcript

item.title: 305. The Demonization of Gluten | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Celiac disease is thought to affect roughly one percent of the population. The good news: it can be treated by quitting gluten. The bad news: many celiac patients haven’t been diagnosed. The weird news: millions of people without celiac disease have quit gluten – which may be a big mistake. Transcript

item.title: 304. What Are the Secrets of the German Economy — and Should We Steal Them? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Smart government policies, good industrial relations, and high-end products have helped German manufacturing beat back the threats of globalization. Transcript

item.title: “Tell Me Something I Don't Know” on the topic of Behavior Change (Special Feature) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Stephen J. Dubner hosts an episode full of the world’s most renowned behavior change experts, including Colin Camerer, Ayelet Fishbach, David Laibson, Max Bazerman, Katy Milkman, and Kevin Volpp. Angela Duckworth (psychologist and author of Grit) is our special guest co-host, with Mike Maughan (head of global insights at Qualtrics) as real-time fact-checker. Transcript

item.title: 303. Why Larry Summers Is the Economist Everyone Hates to Love | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description He’s been U.S. Treasury Secretary, a chief economist for the Obama White House and the World Bank, and president of Harvard. He’s one of the most brilliant economists of his generation (and perhaps the most irascible). And he thinks the Trump Administration is wrong on just about everything. Transcript

item.title: 302. Why Learn Esperanto? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A language invented in the 19th century, and meant to be universal, it never really caught on. So why does a group of Esperantists from around the world gather once a year to celebrate their bond? Transcript

item.title: 301. What Would Be the Best Universal Language? (Earth 2.0 Series) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We explore votes for English, Indonesian, and … Esperanto! The search for a common language goes back millennia, but so much still gets lost in translation. Will technology finally solve that? Transcript

item.title: 300. Why Don’t We All Speak the Same Language? (Earth 2.0 Series) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description There are 7,000 languages spoken on Earth. What are the costs — and benefits — of our modern-day Tower of Babel? Transcript

item.title: 299. "How Much Brain Damage Do I Have?" | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description John Urschel was the only player in the N.F.L. simultaneously getting a math Ph.D. at M.I.T. But after a new study came out linking football to brain damage, he abruptly retired. Here’s the inside story — and a look at how we make decisions in the face of risk versus uncertainty. Transcript

item.title: Bad Medicine, Part 3: Death by Diagnosis (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description By some estimates, medical error is the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. How can that be? And what’s to be done? Our third and final episode in this series offers some encouraging answers. Transcript

item.title: Bad Medicine, Part 2: (Drug) Trials and Tribulations (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description How do so many ineffective and even dangerous drugs make it to market? One reason is that clinical trials are often run on “dream patients” who aren’t representative of a larger population. On the other hand, sometimes the only thing worse than being excluded from a drug trial is being included. Transcript

item.title: Bad Medicine, Part 1: The Story of 98.6 (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We tend to think of medicine as a science, but for most of human history it has been scientific-ish at best. In the first episode of a three-part series, we look at the grotesque mistakes produced by centuries of trial-and-error, and ask whether the new era of evidence-based medicine is the solution. Transcript

item.title: What Are You Waiting For? (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Standing in line represents a particularly sloppy — and frustrating — way for supply and demand to meet. Why haven’t we found a better way to get what we want? Is it possible that we secretly enjoy waiting in line? And might it even be (gulp) good for us? Transcript

item.title: 298. Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Money (But Were Afraid to Ask) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The bad news: roughly 70 percent of Americans are financially illiterate. The good news: all the important stuff can fit on one index card. Here’s how to become your own financial superhero. Transcript

item.title: 297. The Stupidest Thing You Can Do With Your Money | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It’s hard enough to save for a house, tuition, or retirement. So why are we willing to pay big fees for subpar investment returns? Enter the low-cost index fund. The revolution will not be monetized. Transcript

item.title: 296. These Shoes Are Killing Me! | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The human foot is an evolutionary masterpiece, far more functional than we give it credit for. So why do we encase it in “a coffin” (as one foot scholar calls it) that stymies so much of its ability — and may create more problems than it solves? Transcript

item.title: 295. When Helping Hurts | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Good intentions are nice, but with so many resources poured into social programs, wouldn’t it be even nicer to know what actually works? Transcript

item.title: 294. The Fracking Boom, a Baby Boom, and the Retreat From Marriage | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Over 40 percent of U.S. births are to unmarried mothers, and the numbers are especially high among the less-educated. Why? One argument is that the decline in good manufacturing jobs led to a decline in “marriageable” men. Surely the fracking boom reversed that trend, right? Transcript

item.title: The Harvard President Will See You Now (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description How a pain-in-the-neck girl from rural Virginia came to run the most powerful university in the world. Transcript

item.title: 293. Why Hate the Koch Brothers? (Part 2) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Charles Koch, the mega-billionaire CEO of Koch Industries and half of the infamous political machine, sees himself as a classical liberal. So why do most Democrats hate him so much? In a rare series of interviews, he explains his political awakening, his management philosophy, and why he supports legislation that goes against his self-interest. Transcript

item.title: 292. Why Hate the Koch Brothers? (Part 1) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Charles Koch, the mega-billionaire CEO of Koch Industries and half of the infamous political machine, sees himself as a classical liberal. So why do most Democrats hate him so much? In a rare series of interviews, he explains his political awakening, his management philosophy and why he supports legislation that goes against his self-interest. Transcript

item.title: "Tell Me Something I Don't Know" on the topic of Rivalry | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Steve Levitt, Scott Turow and Bridget Gainer are panelists. For the “Freakonomics” co-author, the attorney and novelist, and the Cook County commissioner it’s “game on!” as they tackle competition of all kinds: athletic, sexual, geopolitical, and the little-known battle between butter and margarine that landed in the Supreme Court. WBEZ’s Tricia Bobeda, co-host of the “Nerdette” podcast, is fact-checker. Transcript

item.title: 291. Evolution, Accelerated | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A breakthrough in genetic technology has given humans more power than ever to change nature. It could help eliminate hunger and disease; it could also lead to the sort of dystopia we used to only read about in sci-fi novels. So what happens next? Help us meet the Freakonomics Radio listener challenge. If 500 of you become sustaining members at just $7/month before June 30th we’ll unlock an additional $25,000 from the Tow Foundation.

item.title: 290. He’s One of the Most Famous Political Operatives in America. America Just Doesn’t Know It Yet. | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Steve Hilton was the man behind David Cameron’s push to remake British politics. Things didn’t work out so well there. Now he’s trying to launch a new political revolution – from sunny California. Transcript

item.title: 289. How Stupid Is Our Obsession With Lawns? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Nearly two percent of America is grassy green. Sure, lawns are beautiful and useful and they smell great. But are the costs — financial, environmental and otherwise — worth the benefits? Transcript

item.title: 288. Are the Rich Really Less Generous Than the Poor? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A series of academic studies suggest that the wealthy are, to put it bluntly, selfish jerks. It’s an easy narrative to swallow — but is it true? A trio of economists set out to test the theory. All it took was a Dutch postal worker’s uniform, some envelopes stuffed with cash, and a slight sense of the absurd. Transcript

item.title: 287. Hoopers! Hoopers! Hoopers! | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description As CEO of Microsoft, Steve Ballmer was famous for over-the-top enthusiasm. Now he’s brought that same passion to the N.B.A. – and to a pet project called USAFacts, which performs a sort of fiscal colonoscopy on the American government. Transcript

item.title: 286. How Big is My Penis? (And Other Things We Ask Google) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description On the Internet, people say all kinds of things they’d never say aloud – about sex and race, about their true wants and fears. Seth Stephens-Davidowitz has spent years parsing the data. His conclusion: our online searches are the reflection of our true selves. In the real world, everybody lies. Transcript

item.title: Food + Science = Victory! (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A kitchen wizard and a nutrition detective talk about the perfect hamburger, getting the most out of garlic, and why you should use vodka in just about everything. Transcript

item.title: 285. There’s a War on Sugar. Is It Justified? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Some people argue that sugar should be regulated, like alcohol and tobacco, on the grounds that it’s addictive and toxic. How much sense does that make? We hear from a regulatory advocate, an evidence-based skeptic, a former FDA commissioner — and the organizers of Milktoberfest. Transcript

item.title: 284. Is Income Inequality Inevitable? (Earth 2.0 Series) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In pursuit of a more perfect economy, we discuss the future of work; the toxic remnants of colonization; and whether giving everyone a basic income would be genius – or maybe the worst idea ever. Transcript

item.title: 283. What Would Our Economy Look Like? (Earth 2.0 Series) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description If we could reboot the planet and create new systems and institutions from scratch, would they be any better than what we’ve blundered our way into through trial and error? This is the first of a series of episodes that we’ll release over several months. Today we start with — what else? — economics. You’ll hear from Nobel laureate Angus Deaton, the poverty-fighting superhero Jeff Sachs; and many others.

item.title: 282. Could Solving This One Problem Solve All the Others? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The biggest problem with humanity is humans themselves. Too often, we make choices — what we eat, how we spend our money and time — that undermine our well-being. An all-star team of academic researchers thinks it has the solution: perfecting the science of behavior change. Will it work? Transcript

item.title: 281. Big Returns from Thinking Small | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description By day, two leaders of Britain’s famous Nudge Unit use behavioral tricks to make better government policy. By night, they repurpose those tricks to improve their personal lives. They want to help you do the same. Transcript

item.title: 280. “Tell Me Something I Don’t Know” on the topic of Collections. | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Hear live journalism wrapped in a game show package and hosted by Stephen J. Dubner. In this episode, Tim Ferriss, Eugene Mirman and Anne Pasternak are panelists. The self-help guru, the comedian and the Brooklyn Museum director talk about brainwaves, sugar, stars and — thanks to fact-checker AJ Jacobs — barf bags. Transcript

item.title: How Safe Is Your Job? (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Economists preach the gospel of “creative destruction,” whereby new industries – and jobs – replace the old ones. But has creative destruction become too destructive? Transcript

item.title: 279. Why Is My Life So Hard? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Most of us feel we face more headwinds and obstacles than everyone else — which breeds resentment. We also undervalue the tailwinds that help us — which leaves us ungrateful and unhappy. How can we avoid this trap? Transcript

item.title: 278. Chuck E. Cheese’s: Where a Kid Can Learn Price Theory | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The pizza-and-gaming emporium prides itself on affordability, which means its arcade games are really cheap to play. Does that lead to kids hogging the best games — and parents starting those infamous YouTube brawls? Transcript

item.title: 277. The Taboo Trifecta | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The serial entrepreneur Miki Agrawal loves to talk about the bodily functions that make most people flinch. That’s why she’s building a business around the three P’s: periods, pee, and poop. Transcript

item.title: 276. No Hollywood Ending for the Visual-Effects Industry | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In their chase for a global audience, American movie studios spend billions to make their films look amazing. But almost none of those dollars stay in America. What would it take to bring those jobs back – and would it be worth it? Transcript

item.title: 275. Professor Hendryx vs. Big Coal | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What happens when a public-health researcher deep in coal country argues that mountaintop mining endangers the entire community? Hint: it doesn’t go very well. Transcript

item.title: How to Get More Grit in Your Life | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The psychologist Angela Duckworth argues that a person’s level of stick-to-itiveness is directly related to their level of success. No big surprise there. But grit, she says, isn’t something you’re born with — it can be learned. Here’s how. Transcript

item.title: 274. An Egghead’s Guide to the Super Bowl | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We assembled a panel of smart dudes – a two-time Super Bowl champ; a couple of NFL linemen, including one who’s getting a math Ph.D. at MIT; and our resident economist – to tell you what to watch for, whether you’re a football fanatic or a total newbie. Transcript

item.title: 273. Did China Eat America’s Jobs? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description For years, economists promised that global free trade would be mostly win-win. Now they admit the pace of change has been “traumatic.” This has already led to a political insurrection – so what’s next? Transcript

item.title: Is the American Dream Really Dead? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Just a few decades ago, more than 90 percent of 30-year-olds earned more than their parents had earned at the same age. Now it’s only about 50 percent. What happened – and what can be done about it? Transcript

item.title: 272. Trevor Noah Has a Lot to Say | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The Daily Show host grew up as a poor, mixed-race South African kid going to three churches every Sunday. So he has a sui generis view of America — especially on race, politics, and religion — and he’s not afraid to speak his mind. Transcript

item.title: 271. The Men Who Started a Thinking Revolution | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Starting in the late 1960s, the Israeli psychologists Amos Tversky and Danny Kahneman began to redefine how the human mind actually works. Michael Lewis’s new book The Undoing Project explains how the movement they started – now known as behavioral economics – has had such a profound effect on academia, governments, and society at large. Transcript

item.title: How to Become Great at Just About Anything (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What if the thing we call “talent” is grotesquely overrated? And what if deliberate practice is the secret to excellence? Those are the claims of the research psychologist Anders Ericsson, who has been studying the science of expertise for decades. He tells us everything he’s learned. Transcript

item.title: How to Be More Productive (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In this busy time of year, we could all use some tips on how to get more done in less time. First, however, a warning: there’s a big difference between being busy and being productive. Transcript

item.title: 270. Bad Medicine, Part 3: Death by Diagnosis | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description By some estimates, medical error is the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. How can that be? And what’s to be done? Our third and final episode in this series offers some encouraging answers. Transcript

item.title: 269. Bad Medicine, Part 2: (Drug) Trials and Tribulations | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description How do so many ineffective and even dangerous drugs make it to market? One reason is that clinical trials are often run on “dream patients” who aren’t representative of a larger population. On the other hand, sometimes the only thing worse than being excluded from a drug trial is being included. Transcript

item.title: 268. Bad Medicine, Part 1: The Story of 98.6 | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We tend to think of medicine as a science, but for most of human history it has been scientific-ish at best. In the first episode of a three-part series, we look at the grotesque mistakes produced by centuries of trial-and-error, and ask whether the new era of evidence-based medicine is the solution. Transcript

item.title: The No-Tipping Point (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The restaurant business model is warped: kitchen wages are too low to hire cooks, while diners are put in charge of paying the waitstaff. So what happens if you eliminate tipping, raise menu prices, and redistribute the wealth? New York restaurant maverick Danny Meyer is about to find out. Transcript

item.title: 267. How to Make a Bad Decision | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Some of our most important decisions are shaped by something as random as the order in which we make them.
