The gambler’s fallacy, as it’s known, affects loan officers, federal judges – and probably you too. How to avoid it? The first step is to admit just how fallible we all are. Transcript

item.title: Introducing Stephen J. Dubner's new podcast, "Tell Me Something I Don't Know" | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description “Tell Me Something I Don’t Know” is a live game show hosted by Stephen J. Dubner of “Freakonomics Radio.” He has always had a mission: to tell you the things you thought you knew but didn’t, and things you never thought you wanted to know, but do. Now, with “TMSIDK,” he has a new way of doing just that. This new show is still journalism, still factual – but disguised in the most entertaining, unexpected, and occasionally ridiculous conversation you’re likely to hear.

item.title: 266. Trust Me | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Societies where people trust one another are healthier and wealthier. In the U.S. (and the U.K. and elsewhere), social trust has been falling for decades – in part because our populations are more diverse. What can we do to fix it? Transcript

item.title: How Much Does the President Really Matter? (Rebroadcast ) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The U.S. president is often called the “leader of free world.” But if you ask an economist or a Constitutional scholar how much the occupant of the Oval Office matters, they won’t say much. We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country. Transcript

item.title: 265. The White House Gets Into the Nudge Business | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description A tiny behavioral-sciences startup is trying to improve the way federal agencies do their work. Considering the size (and habits) of most federal agencies, this isn’t so simple. But after a series of early victories – and a helpful executive order from President Obama – they are well on their way. Transcript

item.title: 264. In Praise of Incrementalism | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What do Renaissance painting, civil-rights movements, and Olympic cycling have in common? In each case, huge breakthroughs came from taking tiny steps. In a world where everyone is looking for the next moonshot, we shouldn’t ignore the power of incrementalism. Transcript

item.title: 263. In Praise of Maintenance | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Has our culture’s obsession with innovation led us to neglect the fact that things also need to be taken care of? Transcript

item.title: 262. This Is Your Brain on Podcasts | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Neuroscientists still have a great deal to learn about the human brain. One recent MRI study sheds some light, finding that a certain kind of storytelling stimulates enormous activity across broad swaths of the brain. The takeaway is obvious: you should be listening to even more podcasts. Transcript

item.title: How To Win A Nobel Prize (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The process is famously secretive (and conducted in Swedish!) but we pry the lid off at least a little bit. Transcript

item.title: 261. Why Are We Still Using Cash? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It facilitates crime, bribery, and tax evasion – and yet some governments (including ours) are printing more cash than ever. Other countries, meanwhile, are ditching cash entirely. And if Star Trek is right, we won’t have money of any sort in the 24th century. Transcript

item.title: 260. Has the U.S. Presidency Become a Dictatorship? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Sure, we all pay lip service to the Madisonian system of checks and balances. But as one legal scholar argues, presidents have been running roughshod over the system for decades. The result? An accumulation of power that’s turned the presidency into a position the founders wouldn’t have recognized. Transcript

item.title: 259. Ten Signs You Might Be a Libertarian | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Gary Johnson, the Libertarian Party’s presidential candidate, likes to say that most Americans are libertarians but don’t know it yet. So why can’t Libertarians (and other third parties) gain more political traction? Transcript

item.title: 258. Why Uber Is an Economist’s Dream | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description To you, it’s just a ride-sharing app that gets you where you’re going. But to an economist, Uber is a massive repository of moment-by-moment data that is helping answer some of the field’s most elusive questions. Transcript

item.title: 257. The Future (Probably) Isn’t as Scary as You Think | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Internet pioneer Kevin Kelly tries to predict the future by identifying what’s truly inevitable. How worried should we be? Yes, robots will probably take your job – but the future will still be pretty great. Transcript

item.title: Are You Ready for a Glorious Sunset? (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The gist: we spend billions on end-of-life healthcare that doesn’t do much good. So what if a patient could forego the standard treatment and get a cash rebate instead? Transcript

item.title: Aziz Ansari Needs Another Toothbrush (Rebroadcast) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The comedian, actor – and now, author – answers our FREAK-quently Asked Questions. Transcript

item.title: 256. What Are You Waiting For? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Standing in line represents a particularly sloppy - and frustrating - way for supply and demand to meet. Why haven’t we found a better way to get what we want? item.description: Podcast Description What did Levitt and Dubner learn as kids from their dads? Transcript

item.title: 33. To Catch a Fugitive | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Who is likelier to get to the fugitive first? When a fugitive is on the run, it’s not only the police he has to worry about. A bounty hunter could be coming after him, too. Transcript

item.title: 32. Growing Up Buffett | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What’s it like to wake up one day and realize Dad is a multi-billionaire? That’s what happened to Warren Buffett’s son Peter – who then started to think about whether or not to join the family business. Transcript

item.title: 31. Gambling With Your Life | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Does Las Vegas increase your risk of suicide? A researcher embeds himself in the city where Americans are most likely to kill themselves. Transcript

item.title: 30. Does College Still Matter? And Other Freaky Questions Answered ... | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In our second round of FREAK-quently Asked Questions, Steve Levitt answers some queries from listeners and readers. Transcript

item.title: 29. Smarter Kids at 10 Bucks a Pop | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It won’t work for everyone, but there’s a cheap, quick, and simple way to lift some students’ grades. Transcript

item.title: 28. Why Can’t We Predict Earthquakes? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description We talk to a U.S. Geological Survey physicist about the science – and folly – of predicting earthquakes. There are lots of known knowns; and, fortunately, not too many unknown unknowns. But it’s the known unknowns – the timing of the next Big One – that are the most dangerous. Transcript

item.title: 27. Death by Fire? Probably Not | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Fire deaths in the U.S. have fallen 90 percent over the past 100 years, a great and greatly underappreciated gain. How did it happen – and could we ever get to zero? Transcript

item.title: 26. The Health of Nations | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description For decades, GDP has been the yardstick for measuring living standards around the world. Martha Nussbaum would rather use something that actually works. Transcript

item.title: 25. Is Twitter a Two-Way Street? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description To get a lot of followers on Twitter, do you need to follow a lot of other Tweeps? And if not, why not? Transcript

item.title: 24. The Power of Poop | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Since the beginning of civilization, we’ve thought that human waste was worthless and dangerous. What if we were wrong? Transcript

item.title: 23. Millionaires vs. Billionaires | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Five things you don’t know about the NFL labor standoff Transcript

item.title: 22. Why Cities Rock | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Could it be that cities are “our greatest invention” – that, despite a reputation as black-soot-spewing engines of doom, they in fact make us richer, smarter, happier and (believe it!) greener? Transcript

item.title: 21. Bring on the Pain! | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It’s not about how much something hurts – it’s how you remember the pain. This week, lessons on pain from the New York City subway, the professional hockey rink, and a landmark study of colonoscopy patients. So have a listen; we promise, it won’t hurt a bit. Transcript

item.title: 20. Waiter, There’s a Physicist in My Soup! (Part 2) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What do a computer hacker, an Indiana farm boy, and Napoleon Bonaparte have in common? The past, present, and future of food science. Transcript

item.title: 19. Waiter, There’s a Physicist in My Soup! (Part 1) | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The “molecular gastronomy” movement – which gets a bump in visibility next month with the publication of the mammoth cookbook “Modernist Cuisine” – is all about bringing more science into the kitchen. In many ways, it’s the opposite of the “slow food” movement. In this episode, you’ll hear chieftains from the two camps square off: Alice Waters for the slow foodies and Nathan Myhrvold for the mad scientists. Bon appetit!

item.title: 18. Freakonomics FAQ, No. 1 | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Levitt and Dubner field questions from the public and hold forth on everything from dating strategies and rock-and-roll accordion music to whether different nations have different economic identities. Oh, and also: is it worthwhile to vote? Transcript

item.title: 17. Trashed | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description How economics – and emotion – have turned our garbage into such a mess Transcript

item.title: 16. Exit Interview: Schools Chancellor, NYC | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Having already amassed an eventful resume – the Clinton White House, the Department of Justice, and Bertelsmann – Joel I. Klein spent the past eight years at chancellor of the biggest school system in the country. So what’d he learn? Transcript

item.title: 15. You Say Repugnant, I Say … Let's Do It! | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What happens when the most disturbing ideas are also the best? Transcript

item.title: 14. Do More Expensive Wines Taste Better? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description They should! It’s a cardinal rule: more expensive items are supposed to be qualitatively better than their cheaper versions. But is that true for wine? Transcript

item.title: 13. The "No-Lose Lottery," Part 2 | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It’s the banking tool that got millions of people around the world to stop wasting money on the lottery. So why won’t state and federal officials in the U.S. give it a chance? Transcript

item.title: 12. Is America Ready for a "No-Lose Lottery"? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description For the most part, Americans don’t like the simple, boring act of putting money in a savings account. We do, however, love to play the lottery. So what if you combined the two, creating a new kind of savings account with a lottery payout? Transcript

item.title: 11. How Much Does the President of the U.S. Really Matter? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The U.S. president is often called the “leader of free world.” But if you ask an economist or a Constitutional scholar how much the occupant of the Oval Office matters, they won’t say much. We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country. Transcript

item.title: 10. The NFL's Best Real Estate Isn't For Sale. Yet. | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The NFL is very good at making money. So why on earth doesn’t it sell ad space on the one piece of real estate that football fans can’t help but see: the players themselves? The explanation is trickier than you might think. It has to do with Peyton Manning, with Eli Manning, and with … wait for it … Tevye. Transcript

item.title: 9. Reading, Rockets, and 'Rithmetic | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Government and the private sector often feel far apart. One is filled with compliance-driven bureaucracy. The other, with market-fueled innovation. But something is changing in a multi-billion dollar corner of the Department of Education. It’s an experiment, which takes cues from the likes of Google and millionaires who hope to go to the moon. Transcript

item.title: 8. Who Stole All the Runs in Major League Baseball? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description It was a pretty good baseball season – especially if you’re a fan of the Yankees, Rays, Twins, Rangers, Reds, Braves, Phillies, or Giants, all of whom made the playoffs. But the post-season just opened with a telling event, a no-hitter pitched by the Phillies’ Roy Halladay, which shows what’s been missing all season: runs. Transcript

item.title: 7. Two Book Authors and a Microphone | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description The next chapter in the adventures of Dubner and Levitt has begun. Listen to a preview of what’s to come for the fall season of Freakonomics Radio. Transcript

item.title: 6. Why the World Cup Is an Economist's Dream | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Steve Levitt talks about why the center cannot hold in penalty kicks, why a running track hurts home-field advantage, and why the World Cup is an economist’s dream. Transcript

item.title: 5. How Is a Bad Radio Station Like Our Public-School System? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In this episode of Freakonomics Radio, we explore a way to make 1.1 million schoolkids feel like they have 1.1 million teachers. Transcript

item.title: 4. Faking It | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Do you “fake it”? If so, you’re hardly alone. In this episode, you’ll hear how everyone from the President of the United States to a kosher-keeping bacon lover lives in a state of fallen grace. All the time. And gets by. Transcript

item.title: 3. What Would the World Look Like if Economists Were in Charge? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description In this episode we speculate what would happen if economists got to run the world. Hear from a high-end call girl; an Estonian who ran his country according to the gospel of Milton Friedman; and a guy who wants to start building new nations in the middle of the ocean. Transcript

item.title: 2. Is America's Obesity Epidemic For Real? | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description Americans keep putting on pounds. So is it time for a cheeseburger tax? Or would a chill pill be the best medicine? In this episode, we explore the underbelly of fat through the eyes of a 280-pound woman, a top White House doctor, and a couple of overweight academics. Transcript

item.title: 1. The Dangers of Safety | Freakonomics Radio
item.description: Podcast Description What do NASCAR drivers, Glenn Beck and the hit men of the NFL have in common? Transcript
